Text: Why, O LORD, do You stand far off? Why do You hide in times of trouble?
Context: The psalmist expresses a feeling of abandonment, questioning God’s presence during distressing times.

Text: In pride the wicked hotly pursue the afflicted; let them be caught in the schemes they have devised.
Context: The verse speaks of the wicked‘s pride and aggression towards the afflicted and a call for justice.

Text: For the wicked man boasts of the desires of his heart; he blesses the greedy and reviles the LORD.
Context: The psalmist describes the wicked person’s arrogant boasting and his disdain for the values of the righteous and God.

Text: In his pride the wicked man does not seek Him; in all his thoughts there is no room for God.
Context: The wicked man‘s pride leads him away from God, so much so that God is not in his thoughts at all.

Text: His ways are always prosperous. Your judgments are high out of his sight; as for all his foes, he sneers at them.
Context: The wicked man appears to prosper and disregard God’s judgments, showing contempt for anyone who opposes him.

Text: He says to himself, ”Nothing will shake me; I will always be happy and never have trouble.“
Context: Denotes the wicked man‘s self-confidence and delusion of being unassailable.

Text: His mouth is full of cursing, deceit, and oppression; under his tongue is mischief and iniquity.
Context: Describes the evil emanating from the wicked, highlighting his malicious speech and intent.

Text: He lies in wait near the villages; from ambush he murders the innocent, watching in secret for his victims.
Context: Depicts the wicked as predatory, lying in wait to commit acts of violence against unsuspecting victims.

Text: He lies in wait like a lion in a thicket; he lies in wait to catch the afflicted; he catches the afflicted when he draws them into his net.
Context: Compares the wicked to a lion hunting prey, preying on the vulnerable by trapping them.

Text: Then he crouches and lowers himself, that the helpless might fall by his strength.
Context: Illustrates the tactics of the wicked to overpower the helpless and bring them down.

Text: He says to himself, ”God has forgotten; He hides His face; He will never see.“
Context: Expresses the wicked’s belief that he can act with impunity, assuming God is not concerned or aware.

Text: Arise, O LORD; O God, lift up Your hand. Do not forget the afflicted.
Context: A desperate plea for God to take action and remember those who are suffering.

Text: Why does the wicked man revile God? Why does he say to himself, ”He won‘t call me to account“?
Context: Questions the wicked’s audacity to challenge God, questioning their lack of fear of divine retribution.

Text: But You, O God, do see; for You consider trouble and grief, that You may take it into Your hands. The victim entrusts himself to You; You are the helper of the fatherless.
Context: Affirms God‘s awareness of suffering and His role as the protector of the vulnerable.

Text: Break the arm of the wicked and evil man; call him to account for his wickedness that would not otherwise be found out.
Context: A call for God’s judgment and intervention to stop the wicked and hold them accountable.

Text: The LORD is King forever and ever; the nations will perish from His land.
Context: A statement of confidence in God‘s eternal reign and the eventual downfall of the wicked nations.

Text: O LORD, You hear the desire of the afflicted; You encourage them, and You listen to their cry,
Context: Comfort in knowing that God listens to the prayers of the afflicted and offers them encouragement.

Text: defending the fatherless and the oppressed, so that mere earthly mortals will strike terror no more.
Context: Reassurance that God is the defender of the vulnerable and that He will ultimately make it so that they no longer live in fear.
